After you have invoked and used Eclipse for a while from a directory (say 
c:\eclipse), try renaming the directory (to say c:\eclipse.bak).  Eclipse will 
no longer come up and you will be stuck with a welcome screen.

The failure mode is bad.  Unclear if it is because the name changed or because 
it is not Elcipse (for example what if the original was c:\foo\eclipse and then 
it was renamed to c:\bar\eclipse).

BTW, the presence of "eclipse" as the install dir is API.  I am not advocating 
that we rely on it in the runtime but it is in the doc that eclipse is expected 
to be installed in a dir called "eclipse"

After a short debug session (we don't go far anyway :-)), it seems that is is
the update configurator that does not detect changes.

When the parent directory is renamed, the update configurator does not detect 
any change (it looks at timestamps only).
As such, eclipse runs out of its cached bundles, but the cached bundles may 
have hard coded location values, so things fail. The failure is actually in 
the framework, as the update configurarator successfully starts.

I changed config.ini to add osgi.checkConfiguration=true and that triggered 
the update configurator and the platform runtime to ignore the cached bundles 
and recompute what's needed. Everything worked fine.
(Jeff, how do you pass -Dosgi.checkConfiguration to eclipse without modifying 
config.ini? I was not able to do it that way).

For Jeff/Pascal: what should the expected behavior be when eclipse is 
moved/renamed? Should we keep track of the original install location and 
compare with what is current running?

Fixed in the latest integration build (0514).
The configurator is now checking/saving the framework timestamp as well. This 
timestamp changes when eclipse is renamed, so the configurator reinstalls the 
bundles.
